node.title: Laziness, Sleuthing and Surfing
node.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
node.content: ["There\u2019s a character in the latest Louise Erdrich novel who keeps two piles of books by her bed. One pile is called the \u201cHard Stack,\u201d and the other is called the \u201cLazy Stack.\u201d The Hard Stack contains books about species loss, antibiotic resistance and viruses. The Lazy Stack contains Gothic novels.", "I fell ill last week (nothing serious!), and my attention span shrank to the size of a bacon bit. When I wasn\u2019t trying to remember how much Ibuprofen can be consumed without risking liver damage, I was working through my own version of the Lazy Stack, which is another way of spelling \u201cTreats I\u2019ve Been Saving for an Emergency.\u201d", "\u2014Molly", "Fiction, 1997", "Someone should launch an investigation into why \u201cRhode Island Red\u201d hasn\u2019t been adapted into a mini-series. The ingredients are present: dialogue of lemony acidity; a main character of depth and heft; a premise that sucks you in like one of those Dyson vacuums that looks like a Pixar character.", "\u201cRhode Island Red\u201d is the first in a crime series that features Nanette, a former child prodigy who now scrapes by on what she can earn playing saxophone with mediocre ability on the streets of New York. Nanette is a dead ringer for Grace Jones and holds a degree in French with a minor in music from Wellesley; she is a woman of refined tastes and grim humor who ends up with a dead undercover cop and $60,000 in her apartment. And that\u2019s on Page 18! At one point while solving the crime she goes to a coffee shop to eat a muffin and think \u201cdark thoughts.\u201d Who can\u2019t relate?", "Read if you like: Richard Price, Maurice Carlos Ruffin, wondering whether you can pull off a leather jacket, the TV show \u201cI May Destroy You\u201d Available from: Penguin Random House", "Fiction, 1980", "I never judge a book by a cover, except when there\u2019s an illustration of a manicured hand surrounded by a menacing curl of film stock \u2014 and then I DO judge, and my judgment is: \u201cThis oughta be great!\u201d Such is the case with \u201cDupe,\u201d a crime novel in which Anna Lee, a British ex-cop turned private investigator, looks into the case of a young woman who has died in a seemingly random car accident. Except the crash site had a strange chemical odor, and the corpse featured peculiar markings, and maybe it wasn\u2019t an accident after all\u2026", "The young lady\u2019s death turns out to be related to film piracy \u2014 a surprisingly contemporary topic for a novel published more than 40 years ago! Anna Lee, like any good detective, is pragmatic of mind and strong of constitution. More important, she solved the crime before I did. There\u2019s nothing worse than getting wrapped up in a mystery only to find yourself 10 steps ahead of the sleuth.", "One of the great things about buying used books is the potential to discover a suggestive inscription. My copy of \u201cDupe\u201d was scribbled with the following: To my premiere mystery (lover) \u2014 Merry Christmas \u201981.", "Read if you like: Picking up Britishisms like \u201cnarky\u201d or \u201cbickies\u201d or \u201csquiffy,\u201d Kate Atkinson, Jane Gardam, drinking tea strong enough to curdle your stomachAvailable from: Check Abebooks, eBay or your local library", "Sign up for Read Like the Wind", "Plunge further into books at The New York Times", "See past editions of Read Like the Wind"]
